## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r}
olympics <- read.csv('athlete_events.csv',header=TRUE)
pop = read.csv('world_pop.csv')
gdp = read.csv("world_gdp.csv",skip=3)
head(olympics)
```




```{r}
# rename column
colnames(olympics)[8] <- "Country.Code"
head(olympics)
```
```{r}
head(gdp)
```


```{r}
# drop a colum in gdp
gdp <- gdp[-c(3,4)]
head(gdp)
```


```{r}
# melt
gdp2 <- melt(gdp, id=c("Country.Name","Country.Code"),variable="Year", value.name="GDP")
head(gdp2)
```

```{r}
# rename X from all the years
gdp2$Year <- gsub('X', '', gdp2$Year)
# make Year numeric
gdp2$Year <- as.numeric(gdp2$Year)
head(gdp2)
```

```{r}
# merge gdp with olympic data
mm <- merge(olympics,gdp2, on=c("Country.Code", "Year"))
head(mm)
```

```{r}
# filter to look at most recent olympics
recent <- filter(mm,Year==2016)
recent
```

```{r}
# Fill in medals with a 0 or 1 for medal won
recent$Medal <- gsub('Gold', 1, recent$Medal)
recent$Medal <- gsub('Silver', 2, recent$Medal)
recent$Medal <- gsub('Bronze', 3, recent$Medal)
recent$Medal[is.na(recent$Medal)] <- 0
recent
```

```{r}
# Medal Count
recent$MedalCount <- gsub(0, 0, recent$Medal)
recent$MedalCount <- gsub(1, 1, recent$Medal)
recent$MedalCount <- gsub(2, 1, recent$Medal)
recent$MedalCount <- gsub(3, 1, recent$Medal)
recent$MedalCount <- as.numeric(recent$MedalCount)
```

```{r}
# group by country
country <- recent %>% group_by(Country.Name)%>%
  summarise(medals = sum(MedalCount),
                                GDP = mean(GDP),
                                avg_age = mean(Age))
country
#by_cyl %>% summarise(
 # disp = mean(disp),
#  hp = mean(hp))
```
```{r}
# sort by number of medals)
country <- arrange(country,desc(GDP))
country2 <- arrange(country,desc(medals))
#country <- subset(country, medals >= 20)
country
country2
```


```{r}
# Most basic bubble plot
ggplot(country, aes(x=avg_age, y=medals, size = GDP, color=medals)) +
    geom_point(alpha=0.7)

```
